div.p: I already introduced myself before but
again I'm like Kevin RG I'm the chairman
of the Commission or the cook county
board of review this is Jim Thompson
who's with me Deputy Commissioner at the
Board of Review role and Laura who's a
normal hearing officers and analysts
want to join us here tonight he's waving
back there for those of you on camera
jim was the project manager for the Deaf
system the digital appeals processing
system that I'm very proud of that we
built in 15 months at the board with the
bureau of technologies help from Cook
County my understanding it's the largest
tech project that's happened in the past
five years in the county really what we
talked about it we'll talk about what it
does and what we wanted it to do Jim
will will speak more to the software in
the program development of it I'm going
to talk really as kind of the client the
commissioner and the chairman as to what
we wanted to do we really started with a
purpose of core values of transparency
and openness we'll talk in a secondary
ball at the board of review does what we
deal with property taxes and I would say
for most people they think it's set by a
magic 8-ball that if you shake really
hard eventually your number comes up
that's not how it works at all it's an
evidence based system based on the state
statute but the core value was building
a rebuilding public trust and we knew
that if we move to an online portal
system where the public had filed their
complaints online and on the back office
the project management would work with
the analysts passing the file between
themselves and having their evidence and
their conclusions on a system where the
homeowner that or the business owner the
taxpayer could look at it later it would
it would push what we're doing out of
the shadows and into the light so just
as a background of the board as I
mentioned there's three commissioners at
the board of review we have 126
employees we have approximately nine
million dollar budget the volume that
we've seen at the board is astronomical
we have three commissioners basically
think of us as a three-judge panel the
process really starts with the
assessor's office the assessor puts a
value on a piece of property home a
business this building that we're in
that property owner feels it's over
assess the assessor didn't get it right
they file at the board of review and
it's a three-judge panel myself and two
colleagues of mine every file is review
by all three so we have what we call the
first a second and a third cut so it'll
go to the first Commissioner staff that
hearing officer and analyst will look at
the evidence that's been submitted
perhaps conduct a hearing if the
appellant ask for a hearing review the
evidence make a conclusion show their
evidence or the word of their work of
how they came to their conclusion in the
file and then it'll go to the second
commissioners staff the third
Commissioner staff and then finally if
two of the three commissioners agree
that that value needs to drop it gets
reduced we're completely separate from
the assessor's office we really I used
to be a federal prosecutor before I had
this job so I always explain where the
court of appeals were not the trial
court so that's really our
responsibility to hear rule on a
property owners assessment appeals we
have an extraordinary volume of filing
so as we'll talk about in a second what
started out as a desire to make the
system better we realized was a digital
system that we needed out of necessity
we heard 476,000 appeals last year and
as I mentioned that's 1.4 million
reviews because by statute each of the
commissioners has to review it so it
gets reviewed 3 times 10 15 years ago in
approximately two thousand two there
were 42 thousand appeals last year was
476,000 we had in 2002 long before I got
there they had approximately hundred
twenty four employees about a nine
million dollar budget now the budgets
the same the head counts the same but
the volume has gone up tenfold we knew
we had to do this for the right reasons
of transparency and opening up
government we also need to needed that
we needed to work a tech system so that
people who push carts and worked with
paper files got eliminated and we
converted those jobs into analyst jobs
so one of the things Jim said we should
bring is a wonderful physical prop
because who doesn't love props so this
is a file that we used to have see it's
paper oh yeah if you like we got a whole
warehouse full of them they're awesome
it starts so you would file a complaint
if I can even get the complaint it's in
here you'd file a paper complaint which
by the way was in triplicate and you
file a complaint it would come in we'd
have a date
entry person who would type your
information in the system another
person's job was to print labels see
labels and then it would go on to a file
jacket and then all the evidence that
would get submitted by the property
owner would be copied and put in here or
all the evidence that the hearing
officer and the analyst puts together so
imagine that times 476,000 times 5 and
physically we were running out of space
in the building plus we're having to
have more warehouse space and we
realized like I said we needed to
eliminate the paper and as we see here
this is the appeal form i should say
right now i'm very proud of our gaap
system or digital peels processing
system but one of the things we realize
when we're building it early on is not
everybody in Cook County who wants to
use our services has access to or as
comfortable doing it online they still
some folks seniors people for whom
English is in their first language
people who don't read have ready access
to technology they're going to want a
paper complaint form so we still have
the paper complaint form we just have
far fewer of it and we've been able to
convert those people whose job it is to
do the data entry those jobs are now
analyst jobs so we'll always have this
just it we have to serve everybody but
this is the complaint form the decision
results as you can see when they came
out this is the inside of the jacket as
we would call it the inside of the
folder right here a little folder right
there so you have three analysts ok the
first analysts would look at the file
would do all the analysis would hand
write his or her notes were hand write
his or her calculation hand write his or
her basis for a conclusion and it
literally goes onto a metal cart and it
goes down the hall to the next
commissioner's office and that staff
takes it off the cart works up the math
looks at the evidence puts their numbers
in and it goes on the cart back down the
hall so you know we talk about
transparency in government and having
access to open data it has to be legible
first I mean try-try filing a FOIA are
asking to see the evidence on your file
and trying to understand what any of
these scrawls mean
and when this area up here is empty
because they've only done their work
here and the rest of papers in there we
knew a digital system would just
obviously start with eliminating trying
to read handwriting and what have you
the files from the annals always have
more data than this but this is really
their number crunching in there if
you're an appraiser or an attorney or
real estate professional in that field
you might understand what it means but
if you're a common citizen you don't so
again by putting it online and having
some common legends and in ways of
understanding what those mean we're able
to kind of move forward so one of the
benefits that we had to do with our
vendor we use we're using the on base
platform data bank is is the vendor that
we did a procurement with with the Cook
County Board of Technology bouncer

we do a triennial assessment so a piece
of property is reassessed once every
three years in that three-year period
that property owner can still appeal it
so for example last year was the city
triennial reassessment the Assessor went
through and put values on the properties
in the city everybody in the city could
appeal last year they could also come
and appeal this year they can appeal on
the third year of the try so the reason
ice and about fifty percent of the
property in cook county is in the city
of Chicago approximately another

just didn't even have proper safeguards
to the paper files this is our hearing
room which when we were finished with

December maybe the first week of January
we've moved from having hearings to

wide what are some of the reasons that

rising I mean we just what became a good
government became a practical government
reason for doing it we had to do it
counties goals to get the tax bills out
on time if any of you have heard or
interacted with the board of review
before tonight I'd be
surprise it's a small agency we have a
huge impact though we are the last stop
before the bills go out so schools
libraries police fire all public
services go through the board of review
because we're the ones that help the
revenue stream get to those taxing
districts if we take too long to do our
analysis so if there's a hiccup in it
because as you can see maybe one of
those carts gets lost and we can't
finalize our numbers and our figures
then the bills go out late and if the
bills go out late those local taxing
districts have to go into debt and take
a loan out so for example if we're a
month late the Chicago Public Schools
doesn't have the revenue because our
assessment was late the bills will go
out late the bills are paid late CPS
gets the money late and because of that
CPS is saying well we need it in hand by
sep tember one so that we've got money
to pay teachers and for payroll but if
they don't they have to go to banks take
out interest what they call a tax
anticipation work and paying interest on
that because again we didn't get the job
done right so we knew we had to get the
bills right on bills out on time which
means we have to save tax dollars in
doing so I had no performance metrics
you know literally going down a hall and
looking at cards okay this time of the
year there should be 18 cards another 17
great job hey there's 18 cards now
there's 20 bad job that is in no way

again getting the weeds and you might

had a digital intake system online at
our website up until the system all that

put it on the card so this was our

until we could get this built and as

pretty stable and successful back-office
workflow for our analysts so just from
the timeline we start we issued the RFP
in 2013 if you can all see it we select
a data bank in 2014 and then once we
started up there was really no safety
net because as I said you know we we
were all in on this we didn't in the
first year have paper files and
electronic filing when we flipped the
switch it was all electronic and if this
didn't work as well as we thought or
didn't work at all the bills have go out
late and the county boot would have egg
on its face or not being able to move to
a digital platform so we implemented
depths beginning in July of 2015 again
getting into the wonky nerdiness that is
the cook county property assessment
system we open at the board of review in
july begin we begin opening townships up
and and your neighborhood is really in a
township jefferson township lake
township north township these are the
townships that your neighborhood is in
the city or if you're in the suburbs
evanston township oak park township we
work on the township map we start
opening those up in July we have to get
everything done by the middle of April
because again we finish our work in the
middle of April we balance to make sure
that every appeal that came in every
complaint number has been identified and
had a value put on it we balance that
out as we call it then we go to the
treasurer's office we give the
treasurer's office all of our values for
every single property
Cook County Treasurer's Office matches
that with all the tax rates the bills
get generated physically and they get
mailed out first week of July for a
first week in August pay date and then
once all the money is received in the
first week in August electronic payments
are made back to those three thousand
plus taxing districts in Cook County ok
it's a tight time frame all of the
offices the Assessor the board of you
the treasure of the clerk we all work
together with a uniform calendar to make
sure where everybody is it's
collaborative but a little bit
competitive because we know that if
anybody takes too long on one end
they've got to gobble the time back from
somebody else so again back to the
calendar implementation began in July of
2015 and we closed on time in April 2016
with the system using agile methodology
we had six sprints in our scrum that we
did we would have liked to have budgeted
for more but we've already started

in the change we did a number of
